While the molecular basis of tICAM(453)-mediated neutralization or its significance to interaction of the rhinovirus with ICAM-1 at the cell surface remains to be determined, it clearly indicates a role for the three domains C-terminal to residue 185.
description.heading: EXAMPLE 11
description.p: Cellular Adhesion Assay

Jurkat Y (JY) cells (10.sup.7 cells/ml in 10 mM HEPES pH7.5/150 mM NaCl/1 mM CaCl.sub.2 /1 mm MgCl.sub.2 containing 1 mg/ml BSA) labeled with 10 uCi/ml [.sup.35 S]-cysteine for 18 hours) were preincubated with soluble tICAM-1 or 10 ug/ml indicated monoclonal antibodies for 30 minutes at 37 and then added to 96-well Immulon-4 microtiter plates (Dynatech, Vir.) coated with purified ICAM-1. The plates were then incubated for 60 minutes at 37 bound cells quantified by scintillation counting.

Soluble tICAM molecules were then examined for their ability to inhibit the adhesion of JY lymphoblastoid cells (which express LFA-1) to ICAM-1-coated tissue culture plates. As shown in FIG. 5, tICAM(185) and tICAM(453) both inhibited JY cell binding at identical concentrations of 10 μM, indicating that the LFA-1 binding site is entirely encompassed within the first two domains of ICAM-1.

Previous work has indicated that the two N-terminal domains of ICAM-1 were important in LFA-1 binding, in that site-directed mutagenesis at a number of positions in domains I and II reduce the ability to bind to LFA-1 and a shortened transmembrane molecule containing domains I and II retains one-third of the LFA-1 binding activity of full-length ICAM-1 [Staunton, et al., Cell (1990) 61:243-254]. The relatively high concentration of soluble tICAM-1 needed to inhibit cell adhesion illustrates the fact that ICAM-1/LFA-1-mediated cell adhesion is a cooperative result of multiple weak interactions, as might have been predicted from the strong dependence of ICAM-1/LFA-1 mediated cell adhesion on the density of ICAM-1 [Dustin, M. L. and T. A. Springer, J. Cell Biol. (1989) 107:321-331]. A micromolar dissociation constant has been reported for the CD2/LFA-3 interaction [Sayre. P. H., R. E. Hussey, H-C. Chang, T. L. Ciardelli, and E. L. Rheinherz, "Structural and binding analysis of a two domain extracellular CD2 Molecule," J. Exp. Med. (1989) 169:995-1009], suggesting that low adhesion molecule affinity is a general phenomenon, perhaps to allow for tight regulation of the adhesion process by control of copy number. The identical inhibitory activities of both soluble ICAM-1 proteins toward cell adhesion provide additional evidence that both proteins are correctly folded and underscores the fact that the enhanced neutralizing activity of tICAM(453) relative to tICAM(185) is specific to ICAM-1/rhinovirus interaction.
description.heading: EXAMPLE 12
description.p: Construction of Human/Mouse ICAM-1 Chimeras

We have exploited the fact that the murine homologue of ICAM-1 does not bind rhinoviruses to map regions of human ICAM-1 important for viral attachment. A series of human/mouse chimeras were constructed in order to localize monoclonal antibody and rhinovirus binding determinants within the ICAM-1 structure. Chimeric ICAM-1 molecules were constructed in which human domain I (residues 1-88), domains I and II (residues 1-185), and domains I, II, and III (residues 1-286) were fused to mouse ICAM-1 [Siu, G., S. M. Hedrick, and A. A. Brian, "Isolation of the murine intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (CAM-1) gene", J. Immunol. (1989) 43:3813-3820; Horley, K. J., C. Carpenito, B. Baker, and F. Takei, "Molecular cloning of murine intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1)", EMBO J. (1989) 8:2889-2896] at the corresponding location in the mouse sequence (FIG. 6A).

To construct the human/mouse chimeras hm88 and hm185, PCR amplifications [Saiki, R. K., D. H. Gefland, S. Stoffel, S. J. Scharf, R. Higuchi, G. T. Horn, K. B. Mullis, and H. A. Erlich, "Primer-directed enzymatic amplification of DNA with a thermostable DNA polymerase", Science (1988) 239:487-491] were performed using cloned human and mouse ICAM-1 cDNAs as templates. The murine ICAM-1 cDNA was kindly provided by Dr. A. Brian, UCSD. The PCR primers were used to create novel restriction sites at the boundaries between domains in order to facilitate the gene fusions. The human domains were amplified using a 5' primer GGAATTCAAGCTTCTCAGCCTCGCTATGGCTCCCAGCAGCCCCCGGCCC [SEQ ID NO:24] which contains EcoRI and HindIII sites followed by 12 bases of 5' untranslated sequence and the first 24 bases of the signal sequence. The human 3' primer for the hm88 construct was GGGATCCGAGCTCCACCCGTTCTGGAGTCCAGTACAC [SEQ ID NO:29] which contains a BamH1 site followed by 9 bases corresponding to residues 89 to 90 of murine ICAM-1 and 24 bases corresponding to residues 82-89 of human ICAM-1. This oligonucleotide creates a novel SacI site at codons 89 and 90. The mouse 5' primer for the hm88 construct was GGGATCCGAGCTCAGACCTCTGCCAGCCTGGCAGCAA [SEQ ID NO:30] which contains a BamHI site followed by 30 bases corresponding to residues 89-98 of murine ICAM-1, again creating a SacI site at codons 89 and 90. The 3' primer for all mouse ICAM-1 fragments was GGGATCCTCTAGATCAGGGAGGTGGGGCTTGTCCCTT [SEQ ID NO:31] which consist of BamHI and XbaI sites, a stop codon and 21 bases corresponding to the C-terminal 7 residues of ICAM-1. The two fragments were amplified from 10 ng of cDNA plasmid using 10 cycles with 1.5 min extensions at 72 C. The human fragment was digested with HindIII and SacI and the mouse fragment with SacI and XbaI. Following gel purification the fragments were ligated into HindIII/XbaI cut CDM8 vector [Seed, B., "An LFA-3 cDNA encodes a phospholipid-linked membrane protein homologous to its receptor CD2", Nature (1987) 329:840-848]. Appropriate clones were identified by restriction mapping and confirmed by DNA sequencing.

The same approach was used to construct the hm185 fusion using the human 3' primer GGGATCCGCCGGCAGATCAAAAAGGTCTGGAGCTGGTAGGGGGC [SEQ ID NO:32], and the mouse 5' primer GGGATCCGCCGGCTACCATCCCAAAGCTCGACACC [SEQ ID NO:33]. These primers create a novel NaeI site allowing the fusion of human residue 185 to murine residue 185. To construct hm286, a naturally-occurring NarI site at the boundary between domains three and four in the human ICAM-1 CDNA was used. A full-length ICAM-1 cDNA clone in CDM8 was digested with NarI and with XbaI which cuts at the 3' end of the insert. The fragment consisting of vector and domains I to III was gel purified and ligated to a mouse fragment amplified using the 5' primer GGGATCCGGCGCCTGTCCTGACCCTGAGCCAGCTG [SEQ ID NO:34].
description.heading: EXAMPLE 13
description.p: Site-Directed Mutagenesis of Human/Mouse Chimeras

In order to map the monoclonal antibody and rhinovirus binding determinants within domain I, we systematically substituted human residues for corresponding mouse residues throughout this region of the protein. We chose this strategy in an attempt to minimize the introduction of disruptive mutations which might cause global conformational changes. FIG. 6 shows a sequence alignment of human and murine ICAM-1 and illustrates the replacements which were made. A sequence alignment of domain I with IgG consensus sequences based on structural considerations [Giranda et al., Proteins (1990) 7:227-233] was used to predict the positions of beta strands and turns, each of which were changed in a separate mutation to the mouse sequence. Several single amino acid substitutions were also made which replaced human ICAM-1 with residues from murine ICAM-1 or from human ICAM-2 [Staunton, D. E., M. L. Dustin, and T. A. Springer, "Functional cloning of ICAM-2, a cell adhesion ligand for LFA-1 homologous to ICAM-1", Nature (1989) 339:61-64].

ICAM-1 mutants were constructed using single-stranded template DNA of a full-length ICAM-1 CDNA pHRR12-19 in the CDM8 expression vector [Peterson, A. and B. Seed., "Genetic analysis of monoclonal antibody and HIV binding sites on the human lymphocyte antigen CD4", Cell (1988) 54:65-72] and a Mutagene kit (Biorad, Calif.). In most cases codon degeneracy was exploited to introduce a novel restriction site into the mutant to allow for rapid and easy identification of mutant plasmids. All mutants were subsequently verified by DNA sequencing.
description.heading: EXAMPLE 14
description.p: Deglycosylated Mutants of Domain II of ICAM-1

Carbohydrate structures have been shown to be important components of certain viral receptors such as the sialic acid binding specificity of influenza virus [Weis, W., J. H. Brown, S. Cusack, J. C. Paulson, J. J. Skehel, and D. C. Wiley, "Structure of the influenza virus haemagglutinin complexed with its receptor, sialic acid", Nature (1988) 333:426-431]. ICAM-1 contains eight Asn-linked oligosaccharide chains, four of which are in the second domain [Staunton et al., Cell (1988) 52:925-933]. Since the second domain could contribute to the virus binding site, or be in close proximity to areas of contact, it was of interest to determine whether removal of the sugar residues from domain II affects virus binding. This was accomplished by constructing a mutant ICAM-1 molecule in which each of the four glycosylated asparagine residues at positions 103, 118, 156, and 175 were changed to glutamine.

The domain II deglycosylation mutant was made by simultaneous priming with four mutangenic oligonucleotides designed to change Asn to Gln at each of the sites. In vitro transcription and translation of this mutant in the presence of dog pancreas microsomal membranes directs the synthesis of a core-glycosylated polypeptide of 63 kD, consistent with the absence of four sites of Asn-linked glycosylation (data not shown). The partially deglycosylated ICAM-1 molecule was expressed in COS cells which were tested for the ability to bind HRV-3 (FIG. 7). Essentially identical values were obtained for binding to wild-type and mutant receptors, indicating that the carbohydrate chains on domain II have no involvement in rhinovirus attachment. Lineberger, D. W., D. J. Graham, J. E. Tomassini, and R. J. Colonno, "Antibodies that block rhinovirus attachment map to domain I of the major group receptor", J. Virol. (1990) 64:2582-2587 concluded that glycosylation was involved in virus binding based on the lack of virus binding to receptor made in the presence of tunicamycin. A possible explanation for these apparently conflicting results is that glycosylation is required for the proper folding and transport of ICAM-1 to the cell surface. In support of this interpretation, we have observed that a soluble form of domains I and II fails to be secreted when all four glycosylation sites are deleted.
description.heading: EXAMPLE 15
description.p: COS Cell Transfections

COS cell monolayers at 40% confluence in 150 cm.sup.2 flasks were transfected with 5 μg of plasmid miniprep DNA by the DEAE dextran method [Kingston, R. E., "Introduction of DNA into mammalian cells", in Current Protocols in Molecular Biology, F. M. Ausubel, R. Brent, R. E. Kingston, D. D. Moore, J. G. Seidman, J. A. Smith, and K. Struhl, eds. (Greene Publishing Associates and John Wiley and Sons, New York, 1987), pp. 91-9.9.6].
description.heading: EXAMPLE 16
description.p: Binding of Human/Mouse Chimeric tICAMs to anti-ICAM-1 Antibodies

Cells from Example 15 were analyzed 48 hours after transfection by flow cytometry on a FACSscan using monoclonal antibodies c78.4A, c78.5A and CL203 as previously described [McClelland, A., M. E. Kamarck, and F. H. Ruddle, "Molecular cloning of receptor genes by transfection," Meth. Enzymol. (1987) 147:280-291]. Purified CL203 antibody, which recognizes a site in the membrane-proximal part of the molecule [Staunton et al., Cell (1990) 61:243-254], was provided by S. Feronne (New York Medical College, Valhalla, N.Y.). All of the mutants bound CL203, with between 10% and 40% positive cells in each experiment. Monoclonal antibodies c78.4A and c78.5A were isolated following immunization of mice with HeLa cells by screening for inhibitory activity against rhinovirus infection as described in Example 2 above [Greve et al., Cell (1989) 56:839-847]. Antibody reactivity with each mutant was expressed as the percentage of cells staining with c78.4A or c78.5A compared to control staining with the CL203 antibody in the same transfection (FIG. 8). The percentage of ICAM-1-positive COS cells in these experiments varied from 11% to 48%. The murine L-cell line FT16.1 transfected with the mouse ICAM-1 CDNA and anti-mouse ICAM-1 antibody 3E5 were provided by Dr. A. Brian, UCSC.

The chimeric molecules of Example 12 were expressed in COS cells as in Example 15 and analyzed for antibody reactivity by FACS with monoclonal antibodies c78.4A and c78.5A (FIG. 9B). Since neither antibody reacts with mouse ICAM-1, the binding of both antibodies to the hm88 chimera localizes the epitopes for c78.4A and c78.5A to domain I of ICAM-1 (FIG. 9B).

By replacing predicted beta strands or turns with blocks of corresponding murine sequence as in Example 13, we sought to avoid introducing changes which would alter the conformation of the domain. This approach was successful in that only one of 25 mutations simultaneously affected the binding of both monoclonal antibodies. Only one of the mutants, in which Met-Cys-Tyr-Ser [SEQ ID NO:22] at positions 64-67 were changed to Leu-Cys-Phe-Glu [SEQ ID NO:23], respectively, affected the binding of both antibodies, reducing c78.4A binding significantly and virtually eliminating c78.5A binding. This mutation introduces a negative charge within the F strand at residue 67 which is predicted to have its side chain pointing inward and therefore probably alters the overall conformation of domain I. In support of this interpretation, a mutant which Met-Cys-Tyr at positions 64-66 were changed to Leu-Cys-Phe, respectively, had no effect on the binding of either antibody. Since none of the other mutations disrupted both epitopes, any effects on antibody or virus binding are likely to be indicative of contacts in the area of the mutation, due either to local conformational changes or direct involvement of the altered residues.

Mutations which specifically eliminated binding of c78.4A were exclusively within the region predicted to comprise beta strand D on the four-strand side of the beta sandwich [Giranda et al., Proteins (1990) 7:227-233; Williams and Barclay, Ann. Rev. Immunol. (1988) 6:381-405], and were limited to residues 40 and 43. Thus changing Lys at position 40 to Asp, changing Leu at position 43 to Glu, or changing Lys-Glu-Leu-Leu [SEQ ID NO:13 ] at positions 40-43 to Asp-Glu-Leu-Glu [SEQ ID NO:15] completely eliminates c78.4A binding but still permits normal reaction with c78.5A. Residue Glu-41 which is conserved in the mouse protein does not appear to be involved in c78.4A recognition, since the change to Val had no effect. Beta strands are comprised of alternating inward-pointing hydrophobic amino acids and outward-pointing hydrophilic residues. Thus if residues 40 and 43 are part of a beta structure, their spacing dictates that only one of the two residues is oriented to the exterior of the domain. It is quite plausible that mutation of an inward-pointing residue could influence the local conformation in the region of antibody contact. Alternatively, residue 40 may form part of the loop preceding the D strand.

Mutations which affect the binding of c78.5A are located in the predicted loop between beta stands F and G at the N-terminal end of the domain. Single and double mutants at Asp-71 and Gly-72 reduce c78.5A binding significantly, while reactivity is completely eliminated by changing Pro-Asp-Gly at positions 70-72 to Gly-Thr-Val. A modest but reproducible effect on c78.5A binding is also seen when changing Asp-Gln-Pro-Lys [SEQ ID NO:4] at positions 26-29 to Lys-Glu-Asp-Leu [SEQ ID NO:13], which is predicted from the alignment to form the loop between beta stands B and C. Thus, the N-terminal loop region between strands F and G forms a major part of the c78.5A epitope, which to a lesser extent appears to involve the adjacent B to C loop.

The IgG fold structure places the B to C and F to G loops in relatively close proximity at the N-terminal end of the molecule (FIG. 7), consistent with antibody contact to both. The epitopes for c78.4A and c78.5A thus map to the D strand and FG loop respectively, with a small contribution to the c78.5A-epitope from residues in the BC loop. These mutations define a minimum area of potential contact between the antibody molecules and domain I since conserved residues and tolerated replacements involved in antibody binding would not be detected. Since the interface between antibody and protein antigen is 25 to 30 Å in diameter [Colman, P. M., "Structure of antibody-antigen complexes: implications for immune recognition," Adv. Immunol. (1988) 43:99-132], the mutations which affect binding are unlikely to define the entire contact surface, but do localize key residues of the epitopes. We have found that residues in beta strands D and G, and the F to G loop form a key part of the virus-binding site since mutations in these areas had the greatest effect on virus binding.

The effect of these antibodies on virus attachment could be due to direct masking of virus contact points on the ICAM-1 molecule or to steric effects preventing the binding site residues from penetrating the canyon, or a combination of both.
description.heading: EXAMPLE 17
description.p: Binding of Human/Mouse Chimeric ICAMs to HRV

For virus-binding assays cells from one 150-cm.sup.2 flask were detached with trypsin one day after transfection and replated in 6 wells of a 24-well microtiter plate to give a final cell density of approximately 5 binding assays were done using 20,000 cpm per well of sucrose gradient purified [.sup.35 S]-labelled HRV-3 prepared as described (Minor, P. D., "Growth, assay and purification of picornaviruses", in Virology: A practical approach, B. W. J. Mahy, ed.("Oxford, IRL Press, 1985), pp. 203-212). For each mutant, 3 wells were preincubated for 60 min at 37 C with 1 μg/ml of virus blocking antibodies c78.4A or c78.5A prior to addition of virus, and 3 wells received no antibody. Binding assays were performed with gentle rotation in a 5% CO.sub.2 atmosphere at 37 C. for 2 hours in DMEM containing 2% serum and 10 mM HEPES pH 7.2. The monolayers were washed 3 times with PBS and then solubilized with 1% SDS for 20 min at 37 by scintillation counting. Specific virus binding was determined by subtracting cell-associated counts in the presence of antibody from the values obtained in the absence of antibody. The percentage of input virus specifically bound in these experiments ranged from 16% to 41%. Each virus binding experiment included control binding to cells transfected with wild-type ICAM-1 and the CDM8 vector. Relative virus binding was then expressed as the percentage of virus binding to mutant versus wild-type ICAM-1 in the same transfection experiment. No adjustment was made for variations in expression since the level of ICAM-1 expressed in each experiment was sufficient to allow maximal virus binding.

Rhinovirus binding to transfected COS cell monolayers was tested in parallel with FACS analysis to confirm expression of the mutants. Virus binding to each of the three chimeric molecules of Example 12 was comparable to wild-type human ICAM-1 (FIG. 7), while cells expressing mouse ICAM-1 showed no specific binding. This result indicates that the region of human ICAM-1 which confers specificity for rhinovirus binding lies within the first 88 amino acids.

The results of [.sup.35 S]-labelled HRV-3 binding to COS cell monolayers transfected with each of the mutants is summarized in FIG. 10. Each experiment included FACS analysis of the level of expression and virus binding to wild-type ICAM-1 and CDM8 vector in control transfections. The level of virus binding to each of the mutants is expressed relative to virus binding to wild-type ICAM-1 in the same experiment and each value is the result of at least two determinations from separate transfection experiments. Strikingly, the mutations which produce the greatest reduction In rhinovirus binding correspond to mutations which also affect the binding of monoclonal antibodies c78.4A and c78.5A. Mutants in which Lys at position 40 was changed to Asp or Leu at position 43 was changed to Glu in the c78.4A binding site show a 3-fold and 2-fold reduction respectively, while the combined double mutant exhibits a ten-fold reduction. Mutants in the c78.5A binding site show reduced virus binding which correlate with the reduction in reactivity with the antibody. Changing Asp at position 71 to Gly reduces binding five-fold; changing Asp-Gly at position 71-72 to Thr-Val shows a ten-fold reduction; and changing Pro-Asp-Gly at positions 70-72 to Gly-Thr-Val, which eliminates c78.5A binding, also abolishes rhinovirus attachment. Mutation of residues 26-29 which are also implicated in c78.5A binding produces a four-fold reduction in binding. Changing Met-Cys-Tyr-Ser [SEQ ID NO:22] at positions 64-67 to Leu-Cys-Phe-Glu [SEQ ID NO:23], respectively, also completely eliminates virus binding, but as discussed above, probably induces a major conformational change which disrupts the virus binding site.

Of the mutants which reduce virus binding significantly but have no effect on antibody binding, several involve regions of the domain which are likely to be in close proximity to if not part of the antibody combining sites. These are mutants in which Leu-Leu-Gly-Ile [SEQ ID NO:5] at positions 30-33 in the C strand are changed to Ser-Leu-Gly-Leu [SEQ ID NO:14], respectively; Met-Cys-Tyr at positions 64-66 in the F strand are changed to Leu-Cys-Phe, respectively; and Thr-Ala-Lys at positions 75-77 at the N-terminal end of the G strand are changed to Ser-Ala-Ser, respectively. Only two mutants which reduce virus binding are predicted to lie at the C-terminal end of the domain, in the loops between A and B, and E and F strands.

By transferring intact domains of human ICAM-1 to the mouse molecule, we have shown that the epitopes for both virus blocking monoclonal antibodies c78.4A and c78.5A reside within the first domain, and that human domain I alone is capable of converting murine ICAM-1 to rhinovirus binding. This result demonstrates that rhinovirus binding specificity is imparted by the first 88 residues of human ICAM-1, although it does not rule out the involvement of other domains in virus binding. Our experience with the expression of soluble truncated forms of ICAM-1 and the results of Staunton et al., Cell (1990) 61:243-254, suggest that the first two domains of ICAM-1 are conformationally linked. If this is the case however, murine domain II can substitute for the human domain II and allow virus binding.

The virus binding results suggest that the antibodies recognize groups of residues in domain I which are directly involved in contact with the virus, since the greatest effects on binding were caused by mutations in these areas (FIG. 10). In addition, several other mutations which affected virus binding are predicted to be adjacent to the epitope locations. These results indicate that an extensive area of the surface of ICAM-1 domain I is involved in contact with rhinoviruses. This area includes the N-terminal end of the molecule and beta strands D and G on the four and three strand faces of the domain respectively.

A model of ICAM-1 domain I was docked into the rhinovirus canyon in an attempt to predict possible sites of contact [Giranda et al., Proteins (1990) 7:227-233]. The shape and dimensions of the model allow the N-terminal half of the domain to fit into the canyon and do not constrain its orientation about the long axis. A proposed orientation was made based on maximizing charged and polar interactions between virus and receptor residues. This model predicts interaction between residues in the N-terminal loop regions of domain I as well as in the D and G beta strands. Our mutagenesis data support the general features of this model in that the areas of proposed interaction are those which we find are most important for virus binding. However several of the specific ICAM-1 residues proposed to form salt bridges with canyon residues were altered in some of our mutants which had no effect on virus binding. Two mutations which weakly affected virus binding are located towards the C-terminal end of domain I, suggesting that this part of the domain may interact with exposed parts of the virus surface on the canyon rim.

While the present invention has been described in terms of specific methods and compositions, it is understood that variation and modifications will occur to those skilled in the art upon consideration of the present invention.
For example, it is anticipated that smaller protein fragments and peptides derived from ICAM-1 that still contain the virus-binding site would also be effective.

Further, it is anticipated that the general method of the invention of preparing soluble protein forms from insoluble, normally membrane bound receptor proteins can be used to prepare soluble multimeric forms of other receptor proteins useful for binding to and decreasing infectivity of viruses other than those that bind to the "major group" receptor. Such other viruses include Herpes simplex and Epstein-Barr viruses.

Accordingly, it is intended in the appended claims to cover all such equivalent variations which come within the scope of the invention as claimed, and consequently only such limitations as appear in the appended claims should be placed thereon.

claim.claim-text: 1. An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I wherein amino acid residues Thr-2/Ser-3Val-4/Ser-5 (SEQ ID NO: 16) have been changed to Val- 2/Ser-3/Ile-4/His-5 (SEQ ID NO: 7).
2. An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I wherein amino acid residue Leu-30 has been changed to Ser-30.
3. An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I in which amino acid residues Pro-36/Leu-37/Pro-38 have been changed to Gln-36/Trp-37/Leu-38.
4. (amended) An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I in which amino acid residues Leu44/Pro45/Gly46/Asn-47 (SEQ ID NO: 16 have been changed to Glu 44/Ser45/Gly46/Pro-47 (SEQ ID NO: 17).
5. An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I in which amino acid residue Gln-58 has been changed to His-58.
6. An antiviral analog of ICAM-1 comprising domain I in which amino acid residues Thr-78/Phe-79/Leu-80 have been changed to Ala-78/Thr-79/Ile-80.

7. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 3.

8. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 2.

9. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 3.

10. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 4.

11. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 5.

12. A method for reducing the infection by human rhinovirus (HRV) of host cells susceptible to infection by HRV, comprising contacting the virus under conditions favorable for binding with the antiviral analog of ICAM-1 of claim 6.
